3      I am aware that by trying to simplify any descriptions of critical theory and postmodernism I risk stereotyping them. Readers who wish to read more about the nuances of these theories are encouraged to engage with the readings provided in “Further readings” at the end of the chapter.

5      Of course there is a certain hypocrisy in this because as soon as we speak of elements or principles of postmodern theories, we develop a grand narrative about postmodernism, one of the very things it is trying to reject. This is an example of the way “that the arguments of postmodernism can always be turned back against postmodernism itself” (MacLure, 1995, p. 113). Rather than getting lost in endless cycles of critique, we can remember that postmodernism reminds us to be sceptical, to question the taken-for-granted and consider multiple explanations (Atkinson, 2000).

6      Although some authors would remind us that the idea that there is no one normative ideal we must follow is consistent with postmodern and poststructural theories (Sandretto, 2010).
